title: Informational Toolkit
description: All you need to know about COVID-19

content.title: Whats is COVID-19
details: COVID-19 is the name of the disease caused by coronavirus, originally discovered in Wuhan, China, that can be transmitted from human to human.
The coronavirus 2020 outbreak is officially considered a pandemic by the World Health Organization (WHO).

content.title: How does one get infected?
details: • Close contact with people (within 6 feet) who are infected.
• It may be possible for someone to get COVID-19 by touching a surface with the virus on it and then touching their mouth, nose, eyes, or face.

content.title: What are the signs and symptoms?
details: • Common symptoms include fever, cough, and shortness of breath.
• Other symptoms include sneezing, runny nose, sore throat, and muscle aches.
• Those infected can be asymptomatic carriers of the virus.
• Different people may have different combinations of symptoms, even with the same virus.

content.title: Who is at a higher risk?
details: • Those with serious chronic medical conditions like heart disease, diabetes, and lung disease.
• The immunocompromised, such as people with HIV, those taking corticosteroids, those with cancer and current/recent chemotherapy treatment.
• Older adults.

content.title: How is the coronavirus treated? Can I take antibiotics?
details: There are currently no drug treatments approved, but several drugs that are used for other conditions are being studied to see whether they could help treat COVID-19.
Plasma/antibody therapies are currently under study as well.
Antibiotics are not effective against the virus.

content.title: What sanitation measures should I be taking?
details: • Frequent handwashing for at least 20 seconds several times throughout the day.
• Maintaining distance from others in public spaces (6 feet recommended).
• Avoid touching one’s face.
• Wear a mask if you suspect you have been exposed or have the virus or if you are caring for someone who has.

content.title: What preventative measures should I be taking?
details: • Stay home as much as possible.
• Avoid travel and public spaces as much as possible.
• Practice social distancing by staying away from large groups and gatherings.
• Wear a simple facemask in all external interactions.
• Those who suspect they may have the virus should stay at home and limit interactions with their family/members of their home.

content.title: Should I self-quarantine and for how long?
details: Research shows that after being exposed and infected by COVID-19 it takes between 2 and 14 days for symptoms to begin, with most beginning by day 5.

If you have been exposed, it is recommended you self-quarantine for 14 days, and longer if you develop symptoms or receive a positive test result. Government experts and healthcare providers can guide you in this case.

content.title: How does one get diagnosed?
details: • From one’s symptoms and risk factors.
• A nasal/throat swab or sputum sample.
• A chest CT scan.

content.title: Is there a vaccine?
details: • Currently there is no vaccine.
• Vaccine trials are underway, but may be far from production even if effective.
• According to the WHO, a vaccine is not expected to become available until 2021 at the earliest.

content.title: If you Feel Sick
details: • If you are sick, you should wear a facemask if available when around others in the home or in public.
• Cover your face with a tissue when sneezing and coughing; then, dispose of the tissue and wash your hands for 20 seconds with soap and water.
• Use hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol content if you cannot wash your hands with soap and water - rub hands together until the alcohol dries without wiping it off on anything.
• Avoid sharing personal household items.
• Clean and disinfect commonly touched surfaces around the house daily.

• Maintain as much space between people as possible while in the same room; droplets carrying the virus can travel several feet. When possible, stay in a separate room and use a separate bathroom from other household members.
• Do not give aspirin to children with a fever as it can cause a serious condition called Reyes Syndrome.

content.title: Seeking Medical Attention
details: • The CDC currently recommends: 'If you think you have been exposed to COVID-19 and develop a fever and symptoms, such as cough or difficulty breathing, call your healthcare provider for medical advice.

• If you develop difficulty breathing, pain or pressure in the chest, new confusion or inability to arouse, bluish lips or face, call your doctor or the local emergency room to find out the best way to get medical care immediately.
• Look to your state or local guidelines surrounding best practices, testing criteria, and available healthcare facilities caring for patients with suspected COVID-19.
• Infected or possibly infected individuals should stay home (and avoid travel) except to get medical care.
• Call ahead before visiting a healthcare provider (they may have protocols such as meeting you outside to avoid many sick people coming into a waiting room).
• Do not leave home isolation until you are instructed to do so by healthcare providers in consultation with state and local health departments if you are confirmed to have COVID-19.

content.title: Myth: Packages will infect me
details: Fact: Coronavirus is spread through respiratory droplets, but those may live on packages for up to several days. Take precautionary measures to disinfect packages.

content.title: Myth: I can get coronavirus from my pet
details: Fact: There are no reports of people being infected by animals. However, CDC recommends people with coronavirus limit contact with animals and with others.

content.title: Myth: I should avoid persons of Asian descent
details: Fact: People from Asian descent are not more likely to spread the virus. Disease affects everybody regardless of race or ethnicity.

content.title: Myth: If I am young and healthy, I don’t have to worry about it affecting me
details: Fact: Many healthy people can be without symptoms but still spread the virus and infect the rest of their community; this puts the elderly and people with weak immune systems at highest risk.
There are also cases of young, healthy indviduals becoming hospitalized.

content.title: Myth: I shouldn't wear a mask to protect me from coronavirus
details: Fact: Certain models of face masks protect healthcare workers who care for patients.
Guidlines have expanded and people should create and wear a mask when they must leave their home.

content.title: Myth: Children are immune to coronavirus
details: Fact: Children of any age can be infected by coronavirus. Children with existing health conditions are more likely to have complications.

content.title: Myth: I can take antibiotics for coronavirus
details: Fact: Antibiotics do not work on viruses and therefore do not work on coronavirus.
